text: A <emph>single beat</emph> in music is most often represented by a crotchet. The symbol above represents a crotchet note.
The <emph>stem</emph> of the note can stick up as well as down. The direction of the stem doesn't make any difference to the length of the note.
Click on the picture of the crotchet.
explanation: The crotchet is the black note that has a stem but no tail.

text:
Clap your hands together four times at a steady speed.
You have beaten four crotchets.
Which is the crotchet?
explanation: The crotchet is the black note that has a stem but no tail.

text: A quaver is <emph>quicker</emph> than a crotchet and has a <emph>tail</emph>.
Like crotchets, the stem can go up or down.
Click on the quaver.
explanation: The quaver is the black note that has a stem and a tail. Quavers are faster than crotchets, so try thinking of a fast animal with a tail running across the screen.

text: Two quavers can be <emph>joined together</emph> with a beam which replaces their tails.
<emph>Two quavers</emph> fit into the same amount of time as <emph>one crotchet</emph>.
Quavers can also be joined together in groups of four.
Quavers can be grouped together in beams to make up whole numbers of beats. Four quavers fit into the same amount of time as two crotchets.
Click on the two quavers joined together.
explanation: Two quavers are joined together by their tails in a straight line.

text: Click on the quaver.
explanation: The quaver is the black note that has a stem and a tail.

text: Which group of notes has the same time value as one crotchet?
explanation: Remember that a quaver is half as long as a crotchet.

text: Take a break from the screen and <emph>practise drawing</emph> crotchets and quavers with a pencil. Pay special attention to which way the stems and tails go.
Click on the crotchet.
explanation: The crotchet is the black note that has a stem but no tail.

text: Which is the quaver?
explanation: The quaver is the black note that has a stem and a tail.

text: We know that crotchet notes are twice as long as quavers. Can you <emph>clap</emph> this rhythm?
How about this one?
A <emph>semi</emph>quaver note is <emph>half</emph> the length of a <emph>quaver</emph>, and has two tails.
Which is the semiquaver?
explanation: The semiquaver is the black note that has two tails attached to the stem.

text: Like quavers, semiquavers can be joined together in groups.
Two semiquavers take the same time as one quaver to play.
Which note value is the same length as two semiquavers?
explanation: Two semiquavers are equal to one quaver in length. Remember <emph>semi</emph> means <emph>half</emph>, so a semiquaver is half a quaver.

text: Four semiquavers take the same time as two quavers, or one crotchet, to play.
Which group of notes is the same length as one crotchet?
explanation: Four semiquavers are equal to one crotchet in length, because there are two semiquavers in a quaver, and two quavers in a crotchet.

text:
You have reached the end of this section on note values. You've learnt about three different note values and how they relate to each other.
Before you move on to the next section, take some time to practise drawing the notes you've learnt about.
